title: Black market tobacco trader in Qld racks up $7m in unpaid fines | ABC NEWS
description: Since the Queensland government's crackdown on the illicit tobacco trade, operators are chalking up unpaid fines so large that one player alone owes more than $7 million. The next five largest debtors owe between $1 million and $2 million each. It's the latest hurdle in authorities' challenging bid to stifle the flourishing nicotine black market in Australia. title: British man's visa cancelled for displaying hate symbols | ABC NEWS
description: 00:00 Home Affairs Minister Tony Burke has cancelled the visa of a British man who was charged with displaying Nazi symbols, as the government cracks down on hate speech. 00:37 Anthony Albanese has invited Israel's President Isaac Herzog  to visit Australia, but hasn't said whether Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has also been invited. 01:23 The Prime Minister has announced people who showed "extraordinary" bravery during the Bondi terror attack will be recognised in a new honours list. title: Latest Epstein files include 'fake' documents, US Justice Department says | ABC NEWS
description: 00:00 The US Department of Justice (DOJ) has published almost 30,000 new documents after failing to meet a deadline for the release of all the files last week. But in a series of tweets, the DOJ cast doubt on some of the documents, including what it called a "fake" note from Jeffrey Epstein that mentioned US President Donald Trump. 01:22 The latest tranche also included an email revealing 'A' at 'Balmoral' sought 'inappropriate friends' from Ghislaine Maxwell, raising more questions around the conduct of former-Prince Andrew. title: NSW premier says tougher gun, protest laws increase safety | ABC NEWS
description: Premier Chris Minns says the NSW government is "not done with reform" as sweeping new laws come into effect after being approved by NSW Parliament. The bill passed after a long debate 18 votes to eight and included a key amendment from the Greens on tightening firearms laws for people with suspected terrorist links. title: Questions raised over police readiness following Bondi attack | ABC NEWS
description: In the immediate days after the Bondi terrorist attack, NSW Premier Chris Minns and the NSW Police Force said police "policies" and "resources" in response to major incidents would be reviewed. It's raised questions around readiness for police to respond to active shooter threats, particularly in public places. title: WA Police charge man accused of pledging support to Bondi shooters | ABC NEWS
description: A Perth man has appeared in court charged with posting antisemitic comments on social media, allegedly pledging his support for the Bondi Beach shooters just hours after the deadly terror attack. Martin Thomas Glynn was also charged with having thousands of rounds of unsecured ammunition at his home in Perth's south. Police told the court they also found a bomb-making shopping list and antisemitic material at his property. The 39-year-old represented himself in court where he was refused bail. title: Tough new gun laws, protest crackdowns pass NSW parliament | ABC NEWS
description: After a marathon debate, the NSW government's controversial law reforms sparked by the Bondi massacre have passed parliament.  Under the legislation individual gun owners will be limited to four firearms, while primary producers will be allowed 10 firearms.   The other part of the legislation passed overnight will restrict mass protests in the wake of a terrorism incident. title: Australians prepare for holiday season as Bondi casts long shadow | ABC NEWS
description: As Australians prepare for the holiday season, leaders have delivered a message of hope in a time of darkness. Crowds are returning to Sydney's Bondi Beach in the wake of the deadly terror attack that claimed 15 lives, and locals are taking time to reflect amid the festivities. title: 20 Biggest Stories of '25 - Part Four
description: We are getting to the pointy end of our countdown and that means BIG stories. Perhaps Australia's most famous athlete facing jail time in an overseas prison system. An emotional tale involving a father, a son and an enormous game of football. An entire state split over the future of football in the area. A competitor achieving what no woman had achieved in nearly 150 years. There is a lot to unpack in our penultimate episode of this series.    Subscribe to the ABC Sport Newsletter (https://www.abc.net.au/connect)

title: Leigh Sales on humanity’s best stories | ABC News Daily podcast
description: Some stories are best told first-hand by those at the centre of the action.    It's how the ABC's Australian Story has brought us so many compelling personal narratives and it's a format that's captivated the program's host Leigh Sales.   So which episodes stick in her mind? There's a dramatic rescue on the Franklin River, the widows who found love again, Jelena Dokic's family anguish and the adventures of missing sausage dog, Valerie.    This week, Sam Hawley is joined by ABC presenters and journalists to discuss their best stories and interviews from 2025.   Today, Leigh Sales on the tales she can't forget.

title: What is Friendsmas? Mates celebrate the holidays together | ABC NEWS
description: Despite our screens being filled with images of happy families celebrating together, Christmas is the loneliest time of year for some. But it doesn't have to be. These mates are celebrating the festive season with their chosen family. Cooling off in the pool and sharing a laugh over great food: this is what Friendsmas in Australia's north looks like.  By Gemma Ferguson for ABC News Northern Territory.  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. It's news when you want it, from Australia's most trusted news organisation. title: Festive 'Friendsmas' celebrations combat loneliness and social isolation | ABC NEWS
description: Our screens are brimming with commercials of happy families celebrating Christmas, but for some Australians the festive season is actually the loneliest time of year.  Mission Australia has been fielding phone calls every single day in the lead-up to Christmas, from people who have nowhere to spend it.  The demand aligns with government data that shows the frequency of social contact, both in-person and online, has been declining in Australia for the past two decades.  Many living in remote Australia can't be with family these holidays, so celebrating with your chosen family for a "Friendsmas" can help foster a sense of connection.  By Gemma Ferguson for ABC News Northern Territory.
